awd_titl_txt: RUI: Toward a Comprehensive Theory of Mesoscopic Morphology of Ice
awd_abstract_narration:
This award from the Environmental Chemical Sciences and Physical and Dynamic Meteorology Programs of NSF supports Professor Steven Neshyba and his students at the University of Puget Sound. They study the surface texture ("roughness") of ice crystals in clouds. These ice particles play a significant role in Earth's weather. They influence how the clouds reflect and transmit sunlight. The mechanism by which such roughness develops is not well understood. This project includes experiments and computation. It aims to develop a theoretical description of the ice surface properties. Undergraduate students participate in the work as researchers, co-authors of papers and presentations, and collaborators. Other educational impacts include providing high school students and teachers from Lincoln High School hands-on experiences operating a scanning electron microscope. All of the researchers write computer codes to interpret the resulting images.  Professor Neshyba travels with his students to collaborator laboratories in the Czech Republic and Norway helping them to gain an appreciation for science in an international context. 

In the laboratory, roughness properties of cirrus-like ice crystals are obtained by growing the crystals inside a variable-pressure scanning electron microscope. Molecular dynamics simulations explore the evolution of ice surface characteristics over complete cycles of ice layer growth. A coarse-grained model for ice growth extends the reach of these molecular-scale simulations to much larger time- and distance scales. These results are used to predict interactions with visible light, especially as pertinent to atmospheric remote sensing experiments. A predictive theory of ice crystal surface morphology can be achieved by integrating elements of ice growth dynamics across multiple scales.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on a feature of certain kinds of ice crystals that can be very striking when you first see them: unlike snowflakes, they form the flat-sided (or faceted) hexagonal structures such as the one that appears in the figure attached here called SEM-grown cirrus ice analog. It used to be thought that these facets were flat all the way down to the molecular level, and that such crystals grew because water molecules in the air, having found their way to the ice surface, move around the surface for a while, eventually either leaving the surface to become water vapor again, or finding a part of the ice to fit into.

That mental picture has long had problems -- for one, we now know that the surface of ice is covered by a fluid-like layer, called a quasi-liquid layer, a model of which is shown in the figure titled Ice profile. Molecules of water from the air, as it turns out, stick very easily to that surface, and stay there a long time. So that's one problem with the conventional view. And a second problem is that there is usually such unevenness in the concentration of water vapor above an ice crystal, that it is very hard to understand how the smooth facets seen in the figure SEM-grown cirrus ice analog could be sustained at all; they should grow to be least very rough or bumpy, if not snowflakes.

This work has shown that faceted ice crystals grow by a very different process, in which those recently-deposited water molecules, finding themselves part of that quasi-liquid that sloshes and diffuses across the ice surface, modify the underlying ice landscape in unexpected ways. One of those ways is to create a series of molecular steps across a facet, that get closer and closer together as one goes from the center of a facet out toward its edge. An example is shown in the animation titled Simulation of growing ice. And that pattern, in turn, tends to compensate for those inhomogenites in the overlying vapor field that otherwise would have led to a bumpy or rough surface; instead, those molecular steps make flat faceted surfaces the stablest form of growth.

Part of this project has been to document the conditions that lead to these various possible ice crystals (faceted, bumpy, or snowflake-like). Another part has been to try to figure out why. One thing we have learned -- a big surprise, in fact -- is that, from a mathematical perspective, the processes we think we see leading to faceted ice surfaces has much in common with a theory Physicist Alan Turing devised to explain natural pattern development, now known as Turing patterns, a theory that inludes phenomena as diverse as the stripes on a zebra, and the spots on a leopard.
